Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for 2-year College Undergraduates at Texas A&M University-Commerce
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) Site led by Professors Ben Jang and Allan Headley both of Texas A&M University-Commerce. The Site will provide interdisciplinary research opportunities for a diverse population of community college students in geographically isolated Northeast Texas. Students are drawn from rural areas and are unlikely to have a research opportunity before committing to their chosen career paths. There are 23 community colleges with total enrollment of over two hundred thousand in Northeast Texas that serve rural, urban, and suburban undergraduate students. Approximately 50,000 of these students currently enroll in science courses and yet most do not proceed to college graduation with a STEM degree. This program will target ten student researchers per year based not only on GPAs, but also on the recommendation of the instructors, work ethics, ability to persevere, laboratory skills, and problem solving abilities with special emphasis given to the recruitment of underrepresented groups enrolled in the community colleges in this region. This proposed project will also recruit students in the neighboring areas in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana, which enrolls about 1.0 million community college students. The experiences and momentum gained from the previous REU programs will help to expand the impact on the undergraduate researchers participating in the proposed program. All students will complete basic laboratory and project-based instrumentation training followed by intensive work with faculty mentors on several newly designed collaborative research projects, which will accelerate the development of critical research areas. This will include biweekly oral presentations, progress reports, a final symposium including both oral and poster presentations, and a final report. To better expose students to real world research, two trips to world class companies and institutions that have proven effective in the previous REUs and will be continued.

The REU site will serve as a model for addressing undergraduate research issues among a diverse group of underserved community college students, an important population in the higher education pipeline for STEM enrollments and one that is steadily growing nationwide. The project will not only serve this underserved region but also attract underrepresented groups including female, Hispanic, African American, Native American, and economically disadvantaged students. In addition, non-science majors taking science courses will be exposed to STEM disciplines through exciting information and knowledge presented by mentors and students.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the 2013-2017 REU project at Texas A&M University-Commerce was to continue the previous successful REU projects by providing interdisciplinary research opportunities for a diverse population of community college students in Northeast Texas and the borders of Notheast Texas with Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana areas, who were unlikely to have a research opportunity before they commit to their pre-mature career paths. There were more than 30 community colleges in the area serving rural, urban and suburban undergraduate students with total enrollment of over 200,000 which include majors in chemistry, physics, pre-professional, and pre-engineering and non-science majors. Approximately 50,000 of these students currently enrolled in science courses and yet most did not persist to college graduation with a STEM degree. Nine student researchers in summers of 2014-16 and five in Summer 2017 were selected based not only on the GPA, but also on the recommendation of the instructors, the laboratory skills, and problem solving abilities with special emphasis given to the recruitment of underrepresented groups typically enrolled in the community colleges in this region.

Overall, the 3-yr project plus the extension in 2017 for a smaller group recruited total 32 students from 12 different community colleges in the Northeast Texas region and the border areas. Out of 32 community college students, who did not have prior research opportunities, 18 (56%) of them were female. There were 41% minority students including 9 Hispanic and 4 African Americans among 32 students. One female student in the 2017 cohort was a non-traditional student. 7 of the 32 (22%) REU students transferred to TAMU-Commerce after their REU experiences. All but one, who returned to her original community college, transferred to 4-yr colleges/universities to continue pursue their bachelor and graduate degrees. These REU students produced two publications in peer-reviewed journals and 26 presentations in conferences, such as ACS National Meetings, ACS SWRMs, Texas A&M System Pathway Symposiums, etc., since 2014.

Intellectual Merit: Experiences and momentum gained from the previous REU programs in 2006-2012 had been successfully applied to impact the undergraduate researchers of the 2013-2017 project. All participants completed basic laboratory and project-based instrumentation training followed by intensive work with faculty mentors on novel research projects. Two field trips per year to world class companies and institutions, such as UT Southwestern and Eastman Chemicals, were effective in helping students connect basic research in the labs to applied research in the industry. The visits at UT Southwestern were very intriguing for students to get a taste of how start-up companies operate. Workshops, including presentation and scientific writing skills and research ethics, were very beneficial to prepare students for their career at the next level. The research projects represented novel and critical research areas and the knowledge gained had improved the fundamental understanding and accelerated the development of these fields.

Broader Impacts: This project uniquely addressed the needs of the underserved Northeast Texas region and the border areas with a focus on the community college students which consist of a large fraction of minority and first generation college students. The REU site at TANU-Commerce has successfully served and will continue to serve as a model for addressing undergraduate research issues among community college students, an important population in the higher education “pipeline” for STEM enrollments nationwide.
